awd_titl_txt: NSFGEO-NERC: Collaborative Research: Properties and Mechanisms of the Multiscale Eddy-Induced Diffusion
awd_abstract_narration:
Ocean eddies are fundamental to the distribution of properties such as heat, nutrients, carbon, and pollutants. This project will examine the effects of ocean eddies in distributing properties over time and space. The project uses established theory in geophysical fluid dynamics, a suite of state of the art numerical models, and ocean observations to examine how eddies distribute properties over space and time. The results will be a set of data that can be used to improve representations of the effects of eddies in numerical models of the ocean circulation and climate. The project is a collaboration between the US and the United Kingdom (UK) with the UK component being supported by the UK National Environmental Research Council (NERC) through an agreement with NSF.

This project will explore properties of the inhomogeneous and anisotropic eddy-induced transport at mid-latitudes and examine their importance for tracer distribution. The eddy-induced transport will be quantified by a spatio-temporal map of the eddy diffusivity tensor which will be analyzed to explore the dependence of the results on the spatial and temporal scales used to define the eddies. This diffusivity map will then be used to produce tracer distributions in flows that do not fully resolve the eddy-driven tracer advection, and the resulting skill will be quantified. A hierarchy of eddy-resolving numerical simulations and observations from drifting buoys will be used. The study will advance fundamental understanding of how, where, and why different processes and scales contribute to the material transport and will develop novel methods for estimating scale-aware eddy diffusivity tensors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Ocean currents redistribute such important oceanic properties ("tracers") as heat, salt, biogeochemical tracers, and pollutants. Of particular importance are strong and rapidly changing currents on spatial scales of tens to hundreds of kilometers, which are called “mesoscale eddies” (or “eddies”). The resulting redistributions influence the oceanic environment and Earth’s climate and must be realistically represented in numerical models that are used for forecasts and predictions. The eddies, however, represent a formidable challenge to those models that lack spatial resolution to resolve the mesoscale dynamics, because the most important large-scale effects of eddies need to be approximated ("parameterized").

The overarching goal of this study is to examine those properties of eddy transport that are particularly important for tracer distribution. We describe these properties using an eddy transport tensor, whose components vary in time and space. Once the tensor is known, the eddy tracer transport can be readily calculated from large-scale distribution of oceanic tracers in climate models that do not resolve the eddies. Our analysis is based on several numerical simulations, which provide complete and dynamically consistent data, and allow a detailed analysis of relevant processes.

The analysis of the transport tensors, diagnosed from numerical simulations, reveals several intriguing properties. We found that all parameters in these tensors change rapidly in space and time, and the effects of eddies on tracers depends on direction. For example, the enhanced mixing around approximately 35N in the deep western Atlantic has a large impact on the propagation of tracers from the north and helps to transport the tracer southward. Additionally, eddies act to squeeze tracer anomalies in large parts of the domain, resulting in pairs of positive and negative diffusivities. Moreover, our analysis demonstrated that a diffusivity tensor depends on the tracer it is derived from, formally violating assumptions of a diffusive model, and introducing additional uncertainty in tracer simulations. These complex properties are important for tracer distributions, and, therefore, cannot be neglected in developing eddy parameterizations.

The revealed complexity of the transport tensors motivated us to seek new methods of parameterizing eddies, departing from the conventional diffusive model. For example, our studies show clear advantages in modeling the so-called eddy forcing, which can include all terms that represent effects of eddies. One promising approach to such modeling is to approximate the collective action of eddies on tracers as advection by large-scale velocities. Like the eddy diffusion discussed earlier, this eddy-induced velocity is a parameter that can be derived from model data. The results show that the new method leads to reduced biases in reconstructing the tracer eddy forcing. For example, we conclude that the eddies play a key role in formation of strong fronts, associated with such powerful ocean currents as the Gulf Stream and Kuroshio. Temperature, salinity, and other properties change rapidly across these fronts, which is important for oceanic environment and climate. The new advection-based approach can readily represent frontal formation in coarse resolution models, whereas the use of eddy diffusivity would be more problematic in this case.

Local approaches to parameterization of eddies can lead to biases in regions with strong large-scale currents. Non-local approaches, in contrast, can incorporate a finite delay in the adjustment of eddy transport to changing tracer distribution. One such promising approach is inspired by the century-and-a-half-old idea of Maxwell, reinterpreted in the context of the turbulent transport problem. Idealized simulations of eddying flows reveal marked improvements in eddy parameterizations brought by the inclusion of Maxwell’s effect.

The eddy transport of heat and density are particularly important for the upper ocean dynamics and air-sea interactions. The eddies can create strong anomalies in SST, causing a significant atmospheric response. This result challenges the traditional view that eddies act to smooth SST gradients. Transport of density/mass can lead to both local shoaling and deepening of the surface mixed layer, which in turn influence exchanges with the atmosphere. Both conclusions also mean that the representation of eddies by positive eddy diffusion may not be appropriate in the upper ocean.

This study addresses arguably the most important property of eddies: their ability to influence large-scale distributions of oceanic tracers. The study advances our fundamental understanding of how, where, and why different eddy processes contribute to the tracer transport and explores novel methods for representing these processes in numerical simulations that do not fully resolve these eddies. The study advances the field of ocean dynamics and will be important for validation and improvement of climate models that do not resolve all relevant scales in the ocean. The improvements in the climate prediction capabilities and environmental studies can ultimately lead to societal benefits. In addition to its oceanographic and climate-science importance, this study will have implications for fundamental fluid mechanics, planetary science, and geophysics.
